Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Reykjanes Ridge Evolution Near Iceland
Award.AbstractNarration:
0452132
Abstract
Hey

Abstract
The Reykjanes Ridge is one of the most striking parts of the mid-ocean ridge system on global maps of gravity and bathymetry because of the V-shaped diachronos ridges pointing away from Iceland. It shows the strongest influence of a hotspot (Iceland) of any mid-ocean ridge and is the type example of an obliquely spreading ridge. This project will test two hypotheses for the origin of the V-shaped ridges; pulsing of the Iceland plume versus ridge jumps. The goal is to provide a seamless history of the plate boundary geometry both at sea and on land during the past 18 Ma. Marine geophysical data will be collected in the area from the Iceland margin to the northern boundary of the existing data at 62 degrees north.

The study involves the training of a graduate student and Icelandic scientists will participate in the expedition and receive training in various aspects of data gathering. They will also provide a critical link to the land data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The North America - Eurasia plate boundary south of Iceland, the part of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge called the Reykjanes Ridge, was one of the first areas where seafloor spreading was convincingly demonstrated, & thus became one of the classic areas in the plate tectonic scientific revolution. Additionally, one of the most significant marine geophysical observations made after the revolution, with numerous far-reaching implications, was the discovery of the V-shaped ridges, scarps & troughs flanking the Reykjanes Ridge, pointing away from Iceland. These were thought to be clear evidence for a pulsing Iceland mantle plume. The V-shaped ridges clearly show that something in the plume-ridge system had episodically varied, & as the Reykjanes Ridge had long been thought to have been spreading symmetrically in a stable geometry, it seemed obvious there must have been variable plume flux. Few conclusions in geophysics have been made so confidently. Furthermore, this seemed to prove that Iceland was formed by a mantle plume, because the major alternative non-plume model proposed for Iceland, mantle heterogeneity, couldn’t produce pulsating melt supply to the ridge axis. A great deal of subsequent geodynamic understanding of the Earth has been based on the seemingly incontrovertible fact that Iceland must be the surface expression of a pulsing mantle plume. Although there is an alternative tectonic mechanism that has produced V-shaped seafloor wakes in many other areas, rift propagation, it was never proposed here because propagators always produce asymmetric wakes, & for the past 40 years the V-shaped ridges had been assumed to be symmetric, apparently proving that rift propagation could not have occurred in this area.

 

However, our NSF-funded marine geophysical data clearly show that the conventional plate tectonic wisdom here was wrong. The V-shaped ridges are not symmetric about the Reykjanes Ridge, & seafloor spreading here has not been symmetric. Our magnetic modeling shows that this asymmetric accretion occurred discontinuously, with abrupt changes in both magnitude & sense of asymmetry, most likely as a result of new rifts propagating both away from & (surprisingly) toward Iceland, episodically reorganizing the plate boundary geometry. Thus the ridge geometry has been variable, if an Iceland plume exists it is not necessarily pulsing, & the geodynamic models must at least be modified & perhaps even fundamentally changed.

 

Broader Impacts on Education and Human Resources from our funding included that two of the students involved in the expedition and initial publications are minority students, and six are women. There was considerable Icelandic media interest, including TV, radio, and newspapers, and a middle school science teacher participated on the expedition and maintained a popular website, http://imina.soest.hawaii.edu/HIGP/Faculty/hey/rr2007/index.html. Our preliminary results were presented at the 2007, 2009 & 2011 Fall AGU Meetings, the 2008 IAVCEI General Assembly, & several Icelandic conferences, & were summarized in our initial paper: Hey, R., F. Martinez, A. Hoskuldsson, and A. Benediktsdottir (2010), Propagating rift model for the V-shaped ridges south of Iceland, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 11, Q03011, doi:10.1029/2009GC002865. Benediktsdottir completed her M.S. thesis at the Univ. of Hawaii “DETAILED TECTONIC EVOLUTION OF THE REYKJANES RIDGE DURING THE PAST 15 MA USING MAGELLAN, A NEW TOOL FOR MODELING MAGNETIC ANOMALIES”. Our most recent paper is now in press in Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst.: A. Benediktsdottir, R. Hey, F. Martinez, and A. Hoskuldsson (2012), Detailed Tectonic Evolution of the Reykjanes Ridge During the Past 15 Ma. Several other papers are in progress.
